course.name: Done is better - Build What Matters

questions.question: A leader is waiting for "more information" before deciding. What is the risk?
options: Certainty rarely arrives; define the smallest test you could run with what you have
They will make a better decision with complete information
It is safer to wait until all information is available
No significant risk in this case; waiting is always the right approach

questions.question: A leader delays a decision for three months waiting for "more data." Meanwhile, competitors launch similar products. What principle did they violate?
options: Momentum over comfort: prefer a small step with uncertainty over waiting for certainty
Moving recklessly without any check or validation
Ignoring risk and acting immediately without planning
Always acting fast regardless of evidence or outcomes

questions.question: A leader faces a decision with some uncertainty. How do they balance momentum and risk?
options: Move when you have enough to test, not when you have zero risk
Wait until risk is zero before taking any action or making progress
Ignore risk and move forward regardless of potential problems or consequences
Take the biggest step possible to maximize progress regardless of risk or testability

questions.question: Waiting for perfect information before acting often leads to:
options: Delay and missed learning; you never get perfect information
Better decisions
Lower cost
No significant downside in practice

questions.question: Confusing momentum with recklessness can result in:
options: Acting without any check and repeating avoidable mistakes
Faster delivery
More learning
No meaningful effect on outcomes

questions.question: What should you do with a decision you have been delaying for "more information"?
options: Define the smallest test you could run with what you have; schedule it
Keep waiting until you have perfect information and complete certainty
Make the decision without testing or validation to move forward
Delegate it to someone else who can make the decision without information

questions.question: Why use momentum to learn?
options: Small steps with feedback create learning; waiting for certainty does not produce learning
Momentum is always good regardless of direction or outcomes
Learning is optional and not necessary for successful delivery
It has no effect on outcomes or learning compared to waiting
